text: A roulette table. The PUNTERS place their bets. TWELVE  PLAYERS, nine men, three women. The FACES of the men, all ages, intense, hopeful, fearful. Which of them is JACK?
Now he had become the still centre  of that spinning wheel of  misfortune.
A MAN'S hand spins the wheel. The ball is thrown against  the spin. Hands, faces, chips...
The world turned round him...  leaving him miraculously untouched  The little white ball circles the  spinning wheel.
The PUNTERS'S faces as the ball starts to bounce. All eye are on the bouncing ball.
The croupier had reached his goal.  He no longer heard the sound of  the ball.
The back of the CROUPIER'S hand, his slicked-back short  hair, razor cut. The CAMERA moves around to his face...
To begin with he was Jack Manfred...
whistling sound takes Jack back in time.

JACK is walking through a maze of open-plan partitioned  offices. He ls casually but fashionably dressed, hair dye blond long, a nervous elegance about him, almost  unrecognisable from the croupier's face. He searches for the right office. He finds it. The name o the open is GILES CREMORNE.
GILES CREMORNE, a public schoolboy in his late twenties  comes forward and vigorously shakes JACK'S hand. Jacketle he wears yellow braces. Next to his tidy desk is a slot  machine.
Take a pew, Jack. You look well.  What's it been, two years since we  broke bread?
GILES has an upper-class accent, but an acquired street  manner.
Three years, two months. March
What a memory you've got. Maths  always was your strong suit. What  happened to the moaning Lisa?
She went back to South Africa.
(digging) Did she? (smiles) You were pretty thick at one time.
We all played the field.
GILES frowns at a memory, an implication. GILES'S mobile  phone buzzes. He picks up.
Hi-ya... I'll call you back. (to Jack) Now then...
(suddenly) I want a job, Giles.
(cautiously) All right. As what?
I was thinking perhaps I could be  a reader. You employ readers, don't  you?
We do. For unsolicited manuscripts.  We pay twenty pounds a manuscript.  You might get two, maybe three in  a week. Can you live on sixty  pounds?
JACK opens a pack of Gitanes.
Sorry. This is a no-smoking office,  Jack. You've written a book, haven't  you? I didn't read it myself, but --
A WOMAN SECRETARY puts her head into the office.
Give me ten minutes, Fiona.
FIONA puts a fax on GILES'S desk, smiles at JACK, and goe
Fiona used to read for me.
He winks at JACK.

Let me tell you about our operation.  We like personality authors. People  the public recognises. Celebrity's  what sells books. We can always  find someone to do the writing.  First, we need the face. Then the  concept. (he is reading the  fax) Right now I'm looking for a soccer  novel. Something where a tycoon  buys a lousy team and takes it to  the top. Seven figure transfer  fees. Corruption all down the line.  Violence on and off the pitch.  Steroids. Got any concepts? It  could be a thug story. I tell you  what. Why don't you think about  it. A couple of pages.  The pitch.  Steroids. Got any concepts? It  could be a thug story. I tell you  what. Why don't you think about  it. A couple of pages. (smiles) With plenty of sex, of course.
GILES pops a coin into the slot machine, pulls the handle waits.
Interesting, Giles. I will think  about it.
The machine spits out several coins. GILES takes them.
Let me give you three words of  advice, Jack. Don't give up. Stick  with it. Who persists wins. That's  my motto. Write, write, write.
JACK nods, extends his hand. A firm handshake.
Jack had three words for, Giles.  Go fuck yourself.
Meeting over. GILES smiles goodbye, pockets his slot mach winnings.

The untidy evidence. To the accompaniment of the music, a discordant version, three dog-eared copies of 'The Invent Of The Wheel', A Novel by JACK MANFRED. Worn furniture. A pile of literary magazines. Two elegantly arranged vases  of flowers.  Women's fashion magazines. Books everywhere, including 'Scarne on Gambling', 'The Education of A Poker Player', 'Delta of Venus' and other books by Anais Nin. A woman's dress, back from the cleaners. A framed etching o Cape Town, South Africa, in the eighteenth century.  Finally... Beneath the iron barred window, with a view of the iron  steps down from the street, JACK sits at the dining table In front of him is a word processor. He toys with a glass of vodka, smoking a Gitane, and leafing through a soccer  fan magazine. He starts to touch-type, looking at the  screen, not the keyboard. Words appear, letter by letter. THE BALL... A NOVEL... BY JACK MANFRED. He pauses to drin
A MAN, face unseen, steps into a phone booth. CLOSE ON:  his hands.  It is impossible to tell where he is. He opens his pocket book, addresses, diary etc., and  searches through for something.

He finds what he's looking for: a small photograph, among others of girls, of a ten year-old boy in school uniform. On the back are three phone numbers, two of them crossed  out. The MAN lifts the receiver, inserts coins. He starts to press the numbers. There are CLOSE-UPS of his finger  pressing the sequence of digits, each one CLOSER, longer  than the one before, until...
The phone rings. JACK looks to the answering machine, wai for the voice.
Jacko, if you're there, pick up. I  want to talk to you. It's important.
JACK hesitates, then picks up.
Dad, I'm here.
The MAN is handsome, tanned, 50ish, white shirt, dark tie He is JACK'S father.
How's it going?
The subsequent conversation is INTERCUT between SITTING  ROOM and PHONE BOOTH.
Great.
Found a job?
No.

Well I've got something for you.  In London, I mean. I've been  chatting to some friends. Do you  know the Golden Lion casino? It's  in Bayswater, I believe... They're  looking for a dealer, a croupier.
JACK SR pulls out a cigarette - a Gitanes.
That's not what I want to do, dad.
JACK stubs his cigarette out.
(lighting his  cigarette) Don't be stubborn. The pay won't  be grand, but it's regular. That's  what you need, isn't it? I know  you don't like taking my advice...
(drinks) It's not that.
I've set this up for you. Call the  Golden Lion and ask for Mr Reynolds,  he's the Manager. I don't know him  personally, but I've spoken to his  boss. Don't say no, Jacko. Give  yourself a break.
JACK reaches for a cigarette.
All right, I'll think about it.
I won't. Goodbye, dad.
Just do it. You've got the knack,  you've got the personality, you  got that from me.
JACK lights up.
You understand the punters. Think  about it, you can write during the  day and sleep knowing the bills  are paid.
As he speaks, he watches passing WOMEN.
For Christ's sake, Jacko, don't  look a gift horse in the mouth.  Have you written that name down?  Reynolds, at the Golden Lion. (exhales)
(exhales) All right, dad. Yes, I'll call  him.
JACK is not enthusiastic, but he scribbles the name down  on a pad.
So how are you doing, dad?
Great. I've just started a new  company. Solid financing. It's  good. (pause) I love you Jacko, you know that
Yes, I know that.
Don't let yourself down.
I won't.  Goodbye, dad.
JACK hangs up.

Stubbing out his cigarette, JACK SR. leaves the booth. We now see where he is. A beach bar in South Africa. He walk to the bar and....goes behind it, slipping on his barman' jacket. A WOMAN in dark mirror glasses and a bathing suit is waiting.
(smiles) Sorry to keep you. What'll you  have?
JACK, disturbed by the call, pours himself a vodka. He  looks at what he's written: 'THE BALL... A NOVEL BY...
Jack knew something was wrong.  He'd forgotten Giles' advice. Giles  said three words.
JACK inserts a word in the title. It now reads: 'ON THE  BALL'. JACK drinks. After a moment...
JACK'S VOICE No. Jack knew it still  wasn't quite right...

He types: 'IN THE BALLS'. Then, on reflection, deletes 'I THE'.  Through the iron bars JACK watches feet pass on th street above. A drunk drops a beer can over. The can fall in SLOW MOTION but the clatter is loud.
I want to fuck the whole world  over.
Reception area. The CAMERA turns around the fake glitz of the interior: brass, drapes, polished wood, mirrors, and  moves towards the front door.
Welcome back Jack... to the house  of addiction.
The door opens. Against a blaze of street daylight, JACK' silhouette appears. The CAMERA moves forward to greet him JACK removes his wristwatch.
JACK shakes hands with DAVID REYNOLDS, a cold man in his  late forties, dead behind the eyes.
David Reynolds, I'm the Manager  here. Sit down, John.
Jack.
REYNOLDS examines a file in front of him.
You've been recommended by the  management here. They know your  father. He has a bit of a  reputation, hasn't he?
(frowns) Has he?

In any case, I understand you've  had some previous experience... in  South Africa. (Jack nods) You'll find the rules a little  different here. Before we start,  you haven't got a police record,  have you?
No.
REYNOLDS opens the door. He lets JACK go on ahead.
Where did you go to school?
(surpised) I was at Beadles.
I don't think I know that one.   Private, I suppose.

The full overhead lights give the casino an exposed, tack appearance, devoid of mystery or glamour. The place has  roulette tables and blackjack counters. It is deserted  except for several CLEANING LADIES, vacuuming, emptying  ashtrays. REYNOLDS walks with JACK, talking.
There are three types of casino in  the U.K. High volume. Small faction.  And MOTR. That's middle of the  road. Us.
Do you have a Salon Prive?
We tried. But there wasn't enough  business. The punters like company.
REYNOLDS goes to one of the tables with JACK.
Let's see you handle the chips.
He slides open a box and tips 200 chips of varying  denominations onto the table.
I have to assume the serial numbers  on the bowl and cylinder correspond.
We check every four days.
Why four? And not three or five?
(shrugs) It's the procedure here. Now sort  the chips.
JACK starts to stack the chips in piles from a hundred  pounds to five. REYNOLDS watches. JACK'S fingers work fas In a matter of moments he has the lot stacked.
Stacks of 20. Rows of 5.
Any exceptions?
25 pounds or 25 pence in fours.
Give me 365.
He presses a stopwatch in his hand. JACK quickly sets out four neat piles, three of 100, one of 65. All four piles  are in denominations of ten and five.
Very good. Now take these colours...
He throws a pile of blue and white chips on the table.   The blue are 10, the white are 5.
I want 780, but I want 500 in  denominations of 25.
JACK nods and gets to work. His fingers make Reynolds's  ticking watch seem slow.
(impressed) Very good.
Now at a roulette table, REYNOLDS has prepared the bets  for fifteen punters. It's a set-up to test Jack's style  and concentration. REYNOLDS gives JACK the white ball.
You use two alternating, don't  you?
We do. (hands him a second  ball)
(hesitates) Where's the magnet?
They've been tested.
JACK spins the wheel, throws the ball against the turn.
No more bets.
As the ball begins to bounce, but before it stops, REYNOL turns to a CLEANING LADY who's emptying some ashtrays  nearby.
Could you stop that for a minute?
The WOMAN looks up, surprised. JACK watches, then catches sight of REYNOLDS surreptitiously moving a chip onto the  third line.
I'm sorry, sir, I've called no  more bets.
JACK reaches across, takes the chip and puts it on the  wood Grounding the wheel. REYNOLDS nods approvingly. The  ball stops.
23 Red. Odd.
He now rakes away the losers' chips and pays out the  smallest first, before getting to the major pay-out on 23 It's all very efficient and speedy. REYNOLDS is increasingly impressed.
Haven't you forgotten something?
(thinks) I don't think so.
Wipe your hands.
JACK takes out a handkerchief.
Not with your own cloth. Besides,  your pockets will be stitched.
What happens if I want to sneeze?
You won't. Not without permission.
JACK laughs. REYNOLDS smiles. They like each other.
Fine. Now let's move on.
A blackjack table. JACK is turning cards over for five  punters in an arc. REYNOLDS is moving from one chair to  the next playing each of the five hands.
How many aces are left?
Five.
I make it six.
Five.
REYNOLDS looks down at the table.
What makes you so sure?
It's a rule. Always stand by your  first count. The odds are you're  right.
Good call.
JACK pulls out the shoe.
You want me to check?
(irritably) I said good call.
REYNOLDS walks away. JACK puts the shoe back. He takes hi watch out of his pocket, glances at it.
It had taken him 45 minutes, but  Jack now had Mr Reynolds's number.  The man couldn't count.
Back in the office REYNOLDS is talking to JACK. On  REYNOLDS'S desk is a framed photograph of his suburban  wife and two kids.
Let me just run through a few  things. As a dealer you never  gamble, not anywhere. We'll need  your picture.
What for?
For the database. It can be accessed  by every casino in the country. We  have the same system for punters.
I don't gamble.
Ever?
I don't gamble, Mr Reynolds.
REYNOLDS doesn't pursue it.
Next point. Friendships between  croupiers inside or outside the  casino are discouraged.  Relationships with females working  here are expressly forbidden.
We had the same rule at Sun City,  but it was impossible to check.
This isn't South Africa. We'd know,  because someone would report it.  Believe me, someone always does.
Does know? Or does report? What  would happen if I knew something  like that and didn't report it?
We'd know. There are no secrets in  this casino. You'd be punished.
How?

First offence: verbal warning.  Second offence: written warning.   That one's filed and sometimes  copied to the Gaming Board. My  discretion. Third offence: you're  sacked on the spot. You'd never  work in a casino in this country  again.  There's another rule: you're  forbidden to talk to or recognise  a punter outside the casino. If  you see someone who's gambled here,  even if it's just casually on the  street, you must ignore him. Or  her. You're not married, are you?
JACK shakes his head
Girlfriend?
Yes.
She's not in the gaming business  is she?
No.

A CCTV Centre over the casino. JACK crosses the room,  looking down through a glass floor at the empty casino  below. REYNOLDS walks over to a series of twenty or more  banked TV monitors with many Video 8 tape decks.
This is our Crow's Nest. I'm showing  it to you now, but you'll never  see it again.
Very impressive.
We have tapes in here that go back  six months. Let me show you  something.
REYNOLDS presses a button. Together they look at a TV  monitor which shows an overlook of a roulette table where a WOMAN is cheating. REYNOLDS freezes the frame.

See that?  That was six weeks ago.  The dealer missed it. The guy up  here missed it, but I watch these  tapes after hours. Nothing gets by  me. Now the lady's in jail. It's  easier to take ten million pounds  from a bank than take one penny  from this casino.
Again in the office. REYNOLDS extends his hand. JACK shak it.
You can start Monday week.
Fine.
That hair will have to go.
Fine.
Pause.
Are you planning to make a career  in casino work?
And end up like you?
I just want the job.
Jack, you're not the usual type we  get here.
Mr Reynolds was right. It was true.  Jack was up above the world. An  artist, living in the clouds.  Looking down.
A HIGH ANGLED SHOT of the office, JACK and REYNOLDS. The  phone rings.
Excuse me...
REYNOLDS picks up and listens. The CAMERA descends.

I can't talk about this now... no,  I'm with somebody. They can wait!   I'll be home at the usual time...  all right, I'll call you back in  an hour... (hangs up) Don't ever get married, Jack. Casino  work doesn't mix with house and  garden. Any questions?
The CAMERA reaches a LOW ANGLE on JACK, looking up.
Yes. What's the salary?
The street lamps have come on. JACK is at the wheel of a  Sixties Austin-Healey.
The casino paid its staff monthly  in arrears. He would have to wait  six weeks for his first cheque. He  needed money now.
Under a canopy of coloured lights A CAR DEALER is walking round jack's car, examining it.
(fake American accent) What kind of deal you looking to?
What's the Blue Book price?
That's not relevant. An old car  like this, it depends on the  condition.
The car was a gift from Jack's  father. That's to say, Jack Senior  had given it to him before the  bailiffs arrived.
The DEALER picks at the cracked leather seats, the  protruding stuffing, the chipped dashboard, the rust.
This ain't exactly what you'd call  mint.
He bends down and looks underneath the car.
How about fifteen hundred?
How about five hundred.
What?!
How about we split the diff...  Seven-fifty.
Is that your idea of arithmetic?
I'm not a mathematician. I'm in  business.
Eight-fifty.
Seven-fifty.
The DEALER looks at JACK. JACK stares back. It's as if on is waiting for the other to blink first. Neither blinks.
He suddenly wanted to be rid of  it. 'Hang on tightly, let go  lightly'. It was a saying Jack  remembered.
JACK leans into the open car and takes out his hat and  cigarettes. He has accepted the offer. The music begins..

... And continues. JACK stands, with an unlit cigarette,  in a crowded moving train. He looks at the faces, MEN and WOMEN. He sees PEOPLE reading books. He looks at the TITL Romantic fiction, Classics, Business Management, Thriller Self-Help, Cooking....
Jack imagined people reading his  book. One day he would enter their  heads, play with their imaginations,  test their feelings...
JACK crosses the road. He turns down a side street where  Victorian houses have been converted into flats. There ar scores of 'For Sale' and 'To Let' signs down the street.
He would tell them you have to  make a choice in life. Be a gambler  or a croupier. And then live with  your decision come what may.
He goes down into a basement, closing the iron gate behin him.
JACK unlocks the door, goes in, to the accompaniment of  street sounds and a dog barking.
Marion saw life differently. She  was a romantic. And thought he was  too.

Radio music is playing from another room. An orchestral  version of 'Try a Little Tenderness'. JACK comes in, hang his hat up, looks around. He sees a neatly arranged vase  of flowers that wasn't there before. He goes to the bedro

JACK sees on the bed, an open box and a carrier bag from designer department store. Among the white tissue paper i a simple black silk dress and lace-decorated black  underwear. He smiles and picks up the knickers. He goes t the open bathroom door, from which comes the music.

A radio plays beside the bath. The water is draining away MARION NEIL, a red-haired woman in her mid-thirties, wear a bathrobe with the name MARION on it is examining the  lines on her neck in the half-steamed bathroom mirror. Sh sees JACK, turns with a smile. JACK holds up the black  knickers.
I couldn't resist them.
You mean I won't resist them.
JACK goes to her.
No, no. I'm not ready for you.  There's some vodka in the freezer.
You want me drunk?
(laughs) I won't be that long.
She pushes him gently with the flat of her palms towards  the door.
JACK comes back into the bedroom. MARION pushes the bathr door, not quite closed. JACK tosses the knickers onto the bed.
JACK takes the vodka bottle out of the freezer, pours  himself a glass. He sees two bottles of wine opened, food neatly prepared, ready to cook, an open cook book. He pou a glass of wine.

JACK sits drinking his vodka. Looking up through the barr window he sees women's legs passing on the street above.  On the desk beside the computer is the glass of wine. MARION materialises in the door to the bedroom. She is  made up, wearing the black dress and high-heeled black  shoes, a black scarf around her neck. JACK takes the glass of wine and gives it to her.
You really are a beautiful woman.
(pleased) It's not just inner beauty, is it?
Turn around.
MARION whirls to show off her dress.
You're all I desire.
He reaches for an envelope on the desk. He gives it to  her. MARION opens it. There are several fifty pound notes inside.
Where did you get it?
I. sold the car.
You shouldn't have done that. I  know what it meant to you.
I owe you for the rent. It's only  a car. I can get another.
Take it back. Till you sell your  book.
Come on, Marion. Let's face the  truth. Nobody's going to publish  it.
Of course they will. You just have  to be patient. I'm betting on you.
She raises the glass of wine, drinks.
I'm not much of a bet.
He drains his glass.
You are to me.
She takes her scarf, puts it round his neck, pulls him  seductively towards the bedroom door.
Come into my world.
She winds the black scarf across his face, covering his  eyes.
(whispering) You're my prisoner.
I've got something to tell you.
I want to hear it.
I've got a job.
(startled) What job?
MARION pulls the scarf from his eyes. She wants to look a him.
In a casino. As a croupier. A  dealer.
How did you land that?
It came my way. 450 a week.
(sits up) 450? What did you do, just walked  in and said I want to be a croupier?  Don't you need training?
I had training. In the Republic.
You were a croupier there? You  never told me that. I thought you  just knew some gamblers.
I start Monday week.
From the street comes the whining sound of a car alarm.
450 a week. I've never earned that  in my life. You're an enigma, you  are. A fucking enigma.
Not an enigma, just a contradiction.
MARION looks deeply into his eyes.
You sold the car. You got a job.  What's the third thing? Tell me.
There's no third thing. Don't be  superstitious.
I love you Jack, you know that.
And he half-loved Marion. And she  knew that too.
Outside, the car alarm stops. JACK takes MARION'S head in his hands. She reaches for one of them, examines it.
Are you trying to read my palm?
You've got such beautiful hands.
The hands of a conjuror, a woman  had told him once. Or a card sharp.
Their hands interlock. She leads him into the bedroom.
JACK'S hands are being worked on by a woman MANICURIST.
What line of work are you in?
I'm an undertaker.
Really?
The MANICURIST stops for a moment, looks at him with  curiosity.
A BARBER is cutting JACK'S hair. He goes up JACK'S neck  with electric clippers. Jack's hair is now black.
Do you work round here?
My office is in Shanghai.
(surprised) What do you do?
I'm an arms dealer.
The BARBER stops for a moment, nonplussed.

In front of the mirror JACK buttons a white shirt and  skillfully ties a black bow tie. His short hair is lacque back. He reaches down for his black jacket... puts it on. The transformation is complete. As he scrubs his nails, JACK sees a WOMAN in the mirror.  She is changing her clothes. She pulls off her Indian cot dress. She's wearing pants but no bra. Quite  unselfconsciously, not looking Jack's way, she dresses in her casino clothes. JACK dries his hands. He turns. The WOMAN smiles at him.
I'm Bella.
Jack Manfred.
Hi, Jack. (fits herself into  the uplift bra) Welcome to the cesspit.
Is it that bad?
(starts to do up  her top) How do I look?
Like trouble, Bella. You look fine.
The punters love it. Tits in  uniform.
She laughs.
JACK appears at the head of the table. The PUNTERS look a him, not recognising him.
The usual bunch. They didn't know  Jack, but he knew them.
Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.
A fat INDIAN PUNTER addresses JACK.
Where's the other fellow? Where's  Geoff?
He doesn't work here any more.
Well, let's hope you know your  job.
A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN trying to look as young as possible  throws 100 pounds in cash to JACK.
Tens, please.
She turns to the WOMAN next to her, who looks very simila
Perhaps this man will bring us  luck.
The WOMAN has sensed her friend's interest in JACK. She's jealous.
(to Jack) What's that aftershave you're  wearing?
Never converse with the punters.  It slows things down. Speed is  volume, and volume is profit for  the casino. Aim at twenty spins an  hour.
JACK pretends he hasn't heard the question. In the  background REYNOLDS is watching as JACK spins the wheel.
Last bets, please.

Later. A plastic-looking BLONDE WOMAN, heavily made-up,  sits at the table. She nods to JACK. PUNTERS are placing  their bets. She has 50 casino chips of 100 denominations  in front of her. JACK notes the large sum. The BLONDE puts 2,500 on red and 2,500 on black. PUNTERS  round the table are astonished at the size of the bet and the strangeness of betting both red and black. JACK spins the wheel. Black 10 comes up. JACK takes the  red loss and moves it across the table to the black win.  The BLONDE picks up the 5,000 without a reaction and leav the table. JACK notices that she goes straight to the cashier's desk JACK clears the chips away, starts to pay out. A WHITE-HAIRED MAN on JACK's right speaks to him:
You're new here. You'll get used  to Madame Claude. She comes in  once or twice a week and does that.
JACK nods.

He knew the scam. Come in with  five grand cash. No questions asked.  Launder it by getting a casino  cheque when you cash in. Jack  wondered why Mr Reynolds permitted  it? After all there's was no profit  in it for the casino. Or was there?

Later. A different set of PUNTERS. The wheel spins. A GRE MAN sits at the table. He doesn't attempt to bet. He look around to see a CROUPIER in his late 20's waiting to repl JACK at the wheel. This is MATT. He gives JACK a curious  complicitous smile. JACK collects the chips and pays out.
Thank you very much, ladies and  gentlemen. I'm going to hand you  over now to my colleague. Goodnight.
MATT takes over.
Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.
REYNOLDS appears and takes JACK'S arm.
(quietly) Good work, Jack. You handled  yourself well.
At the table, MATT glances at the GREEK man.

JACK is now dealing to FIVE PUNTERS. He has a 10 and a 5  exposed for the house. TWO PLAYERS go bust. ONE PLAYER  sticks on 19, the next on 20. The LAST PLAYER buys a card for 21. JACK turns over an ace for the house. He twists  again. It's a 5 - making 21. The two losing PLAYERS groan The LAST PLAYER is paid evens for equalling the house. On of the PLAYERS who's gone bust gets up, having lost all  his chips, and leaves.
Suddenly a delayed wave of elation  came over him.
Across the casino an Oriental man, MR TCHAI, is walking  towards the table with REYNOLDS. Behind him is a 6 foot 5 bulging BODYGUARD. REYNOLDS comes up to JACK's table.
Why don't you take a break, Jack.
(puzzled) All right, Mr Reynolds.
He moves his chair back, nods at the remaining PLAYERS. M TCHAI sits down, watched by the BODYGUARD. BELLA comes up, smiles sweetly, and takes over from JACK.
Good evening, Mr Tchai.
Good evening.
TCHAI pulls out a sealed bank packet of 5,000.
Enjoy yourself, Mr Tchai.
REYNOLDS waves to a WAITRESS who comes over.
(to Mr Tchai) Your usual, sir?
TCHAI nods. He hands her a 50 note.
Thank you, sir. Enjoy your game.
50 for a diet Coke. Waitresses  were the true winners in the casino.  They were the only members of staff  allowed to accept tips. On a good  night they could get between 200  and 300.
The WAITRESS goes. The other PLAYERS at the table look at MR TCHAI, wondering who he is.
REYNOLDS walks with JACK across the casino.
Mr Tchai always likes to play at  that table, and only with Bella.
Does he win?
(smiles) He's a good customer.
A good customer is a consistent  loser. Was that what Mr Reynolds  meant?
JACK is changing into his street clothes. The young croup MATT comes up to him.
Where do you live, Jack?
Over the river.
Have you got transport?
JACK shakes his head.
I'm going over the river. I'll  give you a lift if you like.
Thanks.
MATT puts the car into gear, drives off, JACK sitting bes him.
So how do you feel, your first  night? I'll bet you're on a high.
Nice car.
She's my baby.
How long have you worked at the  casino?
Coming up to two years now. (mysteriously) But I was away for six months.
You've done pretty well.
(smugly) Not bad. I have other interests,  of course.
MATT spins the car round a corner.
I'm off to a little watering hole.  Why don't you join me? Relax.
No thanks, Matt. I need my eight  hours.
I'll lay you five to one you won't  sleep. In this job you have to  unwind. Otherwise it'll kill you.  I mean that.
Some other time.
JACK pours himself a vodka, smoking a cigarette.
JACK starts to take his clothes off. MARION is asleep in  bed. She wakes.
What's the time?
I don't know.
Clock beside the bed reads 4.30.
How did it go?
Fine.
He gets into bed beside her. She takes him in her arms.
You're shaking. What is it?
Tension. It'll go.
Poor baby.  This'll relax you.
She starts to massage his neck, his hair.
I loved it blond.
It's only hair. I haven't changed.
MARION is dressed in a suit, preparing to leave. She thro her nightgown into a laundry basket. JACK is asleep. She  bends to kiss him. He wakes.
When you get home, I'm asleep.  When I leave home, you're asleep.
(dreamily) I'll see you in my dreams.
MARION drops a set of keys into her bag, glances at JACK' covered computer. She draws the curtain back. Daylight  illuminates the old etching of Cape Town.
JANI DE VILLIERS is 30-something, blonde, tanned,  expensively dressed in designer clothes. She gives JACK  ten 50 notes.
In 20s, please...

He slots the cash into the "bank" beneath the table, then counts out 500 in 20 chips. He slides the chips towards  her, looks at her. She smiles. There are ten other PEOPLE at the roulette table. An ARAB LOOKING MAN with a moustache behind JANI is looking down  the front of her dress.
(frowns) Place your bets.
Around the table the PUNTERS move their chips onto number lines, colours. JANI throws three chips to JACK and calls the numbers:
JACK places them for her.
Jack could see this woman was an  experienced gambler. Professionals  always place their bets through  the croupier. That way there are  no comebacks.

The wheel spins, 11 is the number. JACK calls the number  and puts the 'dolly' on 11. JANI smiles faintly. JACK pay out across the table. JANI leaves two chips on 11 The MAN behind JANI puts his chips on 11.  JANI glances up at him She sees the MAN is betting with her. JACK spins the whee again. 33 comes up.

JANI bets again on number 11. The MAN follows suit. The  wheel spins. JACK watches the table. JANI glances at him. The MAN moves closer to the table to one side of JANI.  Concealed in his hand is a chip. As the ball bounces roun and lands again on number 11, the MAN deftly adds the chi to the square. JACK clocks it.
I'm sorry, sir, that's a late bet.
(in Arabic accent) What are you talking about? It's  11, I've won. With this lady.
(carefully) You've won with the two chips you  placed earlier, but the third chip  was a late bet.
I put them on together.
I'm afraid that's not so, sir.
REYNOLDS, who has been watching the tables, sees the  beginning of an incident. He comes over. The MAN is getti angry. JANI watches.
Now look here, you...
Is there a problem, sir?
Yes. This croupier is accusing me  of cheating.
It was a late bet. This gentleman  has been following the lady's  numbers and...
The MAN interrupts JACK and touches JANI's arm.
(to Jani) Do you think I cheated?
JACK and REYNOLDS wait. JACK glances at JANI.
In my opinion... it was a late  bet.
I think we should talk about this,  sir. Away from the table.
(angrily) No. I won. I want to be paid.
He bangs his fist on the felt. JACK waits for REYNOLDS'S  decision. REYNOLDS looks at JACK.
Pay the gentleman. In full.

REYNOLDS steps back, JACK pays out JANI and the MAN. The  MAN takes his winnings. He looks at JACK with hatred, the leaves the table. REYNOLDS watches him, looks to JACK and nods. JANI collec her winnings and throws two chips to JACK. She stands up  to leave.
I'm sorry, madam, we don't accept  gratuities in the UK. It's different  in South Africa.
(surprised) You know where I'm from?
JACK nods and gives her back the two chips.
I've lived there.
(sweetly) Well, thank you anyway.
JACK watches her leave.
Bright woman, he thought. She knew  the rule of gold. Quit when you're  ahead.
JANI heads towards the cashier. JACK sees REYNOLDS arguin with the irate ARABIC MAN near the entrance. He looks back to the table.
Place your bets.
On his way out the ARABIC MAN looks towards JACK and make an occult sign with his hand.

It is late. There are few PUNTERS left at the tables. JAC tidies up his table, which is next to MATT's. He looks  across at MATT and sees the GREEK MAN who was at the tabl the first night when MATT took over. The GREEK wins on a  number. MATT clears the table and counts out the GREEK'S  winnings, quickly and efficiently. JACK stiffens. He sees that something is wrong. MATT move piles of chips across to the GREEK, who doesn't look up.  JACK glances in the direction of the hidden video cameras and the crows' nest. REYNOLDS is in the back-ground, has  seen nothing untoward. JACK watches the GREEK pick up his winnings and leave.
Again MATT is driving JACK home.
(hesitantly) Look Matt, there's something I  have to say to you. I saw you  cheating.
(violently) What the fuck are you talking about?
That Greek guy who won at the end.  You paid him out in 25s not 20s.
(angry) I don't cheat, Jack. You've got it  wrong.
I'm not going to report it.
MATT slams on the brakes. The car comes to an abrupt stop MATT turns to JACK, furious.
What are you, a cop?
If I see you do it again, I'll  report it.
I don't get you. Even if it was  true, which it isn't, what the  fuck difference would it make to  you?
Because if a supervisor knew I'd  seen you and I hadn't reported it,  I'd lose my job as well. And I  can't afford that.

So it's Mr Clean. Wise up, Jack,  this whole business is bent. The  casino is nothing but legal theft.  And that's OK. It's the system.  Half the punters who come in are  using stolen money, drug money,  they haven't earned it. We earn  our money. (softens) I'm on your side, Jack. I don't  need an enemy.
You're talking about complicity.
I don't know what that means. I'm  talking about not rocking the boat.
MATT holds out his hand for JACK. JACK shakes it. MATT  grins.
OK, now let's unwind.
He puts the car into gear and drives off.
Matt was an escape artist. Like  Jack's father.
MATT's car pulls up in the parking lot at the back of the restaurant.  He and JACK get out of the car and go throug the open kitchen door.
The kitchen is full of people, some involved in cooking,  some standing around smoking and drinking, mostly Greek.
Hey, Andros!
He shakes hands with a GUY who looks like the owner.
This is Jack.
JACK shakes hands too. They cross the kitchen and go thro a bead curtain. Piped Greek music is playing.

A smoke-filled private dining room. There is a poker game in Progress. FIVE MEN are playing, a DOZEN GIRLS are dott about watching. There is a trestle table laden with Greek food, from stews to salad, buffet-style. An improvised ba with ouzo, vodka and wine. It's help-yourself.
Who are these guys?
Mostly people in the casino  business. A few drug dealers.
And the girls?
Just girls. What are you drinking?
Vodka. Straight. On the rocks.
Good call. Help yourself.
JACK pours himself a vodka, scoops up some ice with his  hand from a bucket. Clouds of smoke envelop him. The nois is close to deafening.
Does Bella come here?
That bitch? No.
The poker game. A MAN with fair hair gets up, kisses a  GIRL whose dress is a bathing suit, puts his arm round he and they wander off. MATT is at the table. JACK is  replenishing his vodka.
Hey Jack, join us.
No thanks.
(laughs) Don't worry, I won't report you!
I don't gamble.
GIRL appears behind JACK's shoulder.
You don't gamble, but do you smoke?
The GIRL has a joint in her over-ringed hand. She is dres in purple Indian cotton.
Sometimes.
(hands him the  smoking joint) How about now?
She blows smoke in his face. JACK drains his vodka, pours himself another.

JACK comes into the Gents, another smoke-filled room. Thr or four MEN are arguing over a drug deal, standing in fro of the urinal. One of them has an envelope full of cash,  another a packet of drugs. JACK goes to a lavatory stall, opens the door. In the sta the fair-haired MAN who was at Matt's table is sitting on the lavatory, his trousers round his ankles. The GIRL in  the bathing suit is sitting on his thighs, bobbing up and down. JACK sees a butterfly tattoo on her left cheek, the Queen of Spades.
Marion. I'm on my way...
JACK puts his arm on MATT's shoulder at the poker table.
I'm off. I need to sleep.
Loosen up, Jack. If you don't,  this job'll get to you. The  pressure's too much, believe me,  it'll break you.
"The world breaks everyone, and  afterwards many are strong in the  broken places." Ernest Hemingway.
JACK turns and leaves, helping himself to another drink.
Wasn't he the one who shot himself?
JACK comes to the flat. He is drunk. He starts across the dark room. Suddenly the light comes on. JACK turns to see MARION, sitting in a chair in her night-dress.
Where've you been? I've got to  give evidence in court at nine.
Don't play the cop with me, Marion.
Take that back! (furious) Fucking take that back. I'm not a  cop any more.
I take it back. You're not a cop  any more. You're a store detective.
Are you drunk?
Probably.
This fucking job's getting to you.  You haven't written a fucking word  since you started.
Do you have to swear all the time?

(hurt) Well, that's my poor upbringing. I  didn't go to no private school. I  haven't got no class. I want to  live with a writer. Not a fucking  croupier. I don't even know what  the word means. Croupier.
Marion, stop this.
(near to tears) What do I mean to you? I want to  know. Tell me.
There is a pause.
You're my conscience.
Haven't you got a conscience of  your own?
JACK has no answer. He goes into the bathroom.

The computer is still covered. JACK is standing at the  table dealing cards, practising. One card slips. He swear silently. He flexes his fingers, cracks his knuckle joint He looks at a skirt, legs, high heels, Passing above the  barred window.
JACK emerges from the Underground, one of the CROWD.
JACK goes into a large Department Store.

MARION is store-walking in the women's underwear departme It is Sale time. Baskets of tights and knickers on displa CUSTOMERS are rummaging. She is on the look-out for thiev She jumps as JACK places his hand on her hip.
What are you doing here? (looks round  nervously) You know the rules.
What about a drink on the way home?
I don't finish till eight. Make it  nine and you're on.
I'm on at nine.
Well, that's our life now, isn't  it?

JACK pauses in front of an airline office. There is a lar picture of Cape Town, and a special ticket offer. JANI comes out of the office. Her hair, tied back earlier in the casino, is now glamorously fluffed out. She sees  JACK. He doesn't see her.
Thinking of going back?
JACK is startled. He doesn't recognise her for a moment.  Then...
Oh hello.
(smiling) You know what? I'd like to buy you  a drink.
It's against the rules. Dealers  are forbidden to talk to punters.
That's stupid. What are the odds  of you being seen with me?
Impossible to calculate.
Jack knew that, in reality, all  odds are calculable.
The Art Deco bar. Expensive PEOPLE around. JANI and JACK  are installed on a sofa. A WAITER puts down two Martinis.
(raises her glass) To coincidence.
(drinks) There's a casino in this hotel.
I'm not much of a gambler really.  I just like this bar.
So why did you come to my casino?
I was at a loose end. A friend of  a friend gave me a courtesy  membership.
First visit to London?
No, no. I come every couple of  years. I always think I'm going to  stay. I'm from Cape Town originally
I was born in the Transkei, on the  Wild Coast.
Near the casino.
In the casino.
Now there's a coincidence. My father  used to gamble there.
Your father?
I loved the atmosphere. But it  destroyed my poor mother.
The debts.
And the lies. Gamblers are born  liars.
(nods) And superstitious too. It's like  witchcraft.
That's Africa. There's an African  in all of us, isn't there?
We all came from Africa, supposedly.
Do you believe in astrology?
Absolutely not. But then, I'm a  Gemini and Geminis don't believe  in astrology.
JANI laughs out loud.
You know, you don't strike me as a  typical croupier.
JANI drinks. JACK notices her wedding ring. JANI catches  the look.
I'm not married. I wear it to keep  the flies off. (looks at her watch) I must go. Let me pay for this.
Absolutely not.
Toss you for it.
I don't gamble.
JANI nods, stands up, takes out a notepad and pen. She  looks round feigning conspiracy.
(low voice) I know this is verboten, but if  you feel like a chat or maybe  dinner, give me a call.
She scribbles her name and phone number on the pad, tears off the page, gives it to him.
I'll understand if you don't. (smiles) But I hope you do.
She leaves. JACK watches her go, looks at the page she's  given him.
In front of a mirror JACK trims his hair with nail scisso He is dressed in his croupier's uniform. He straightens  his bow tie.
He didn't know why, but he'd started  to dress for the casino at home...
JACK sits in the compartment.
... like a musician in his tuxedo,  going to the concert hall on public  transport...

An ARAB at the end of the table kisses all his 50 chips  and sets them out on the table. The wheel spins. JACK loo round at the PUNTERS. The ball bounces, falls on zero. Everybody loses. Many  groans. A MEDITERRANEAN-LOOKING MAN with a gold bracelet coughs. gob of phlegm from his mouth lands on a pile of chips tha JACK is raking away. A WOMAN in her mid-thirties is  appalled.
Animal!
Would you mind being more careful,  sir.
I've got 'flu.
He coughs again, but into a handkerchief.
Then go back home. To the zoo!
JACK clears the piles of chips to one side. He signals to a SUPERVISOR. The SUPERVISOR hurries over.
This gentleman accidentally coughed  onto these chips. I don't think it  would be hygienic to stack them...
The SUPERVISOR signals a WAITRESS over.
Agnes. These chips have to be  counted and put into the steamer.
Yuck.
She looks at JACK, grimaces, and takes the chips away.
The last PUNTERS are leaving. The overhead lights come on A CROUPIER is wheeling away a trolley with thousands of  chips. TWO MEN are covering the tables with shrouds.
REYNOLDS watches as JACK and MATT count the thousands of  pounds, putting them in piles. Behind them is a large ope safe.
I can't give you a lift back  tonight.
Don't worry.
REYNOLDS places the notes in steel boxes.
JACK, comes out. BELLA hurries after him, following him  round the corner.
(calling) Jack. Do you need a ride?
No. Thanks.
My car's in the garage.
Maybe another time.
I'll take you up on that.
(pleasantly) Goodnight.
He straightens his hat and walks off. BELLA walks the oth way.

A MAN lurks in the shadows ahead of JACK. JACK doesn't se him. But as he comes past, the MAN steps out blocking JAC way. He is the Arabic-looking MAN JACK earlier caught  cheating at the casino with JANI.
You don't recognise me? You had me  barred. You fucking little worm.
Wait a minute. You got yourself  barred.
It was you, you shit.

The MAN reaches forward and grabs JACK'S tie. He yanks it with farce. JACK gasps. He rams his elbow into the MAN'S  chest. The MAN kicks JACK on the shins. JACK topples. The MAN  leaps at him. JACK, knees him in the groin. The fight is untidy and vicious. Both men collapse  struggling onto the pavement. A car appears, a Mini-Cooper. BELLA is driving. She sees  the fight. JACK'S nose is bleeding. The MAN kicks him in the back.  JACK yells with pain, gets to his feet.
Now I'm going to kill you.
He boots the MAN in the head. BELLA gets out of her car  and runs over to them.
Jack!
The MAN is screening under JACK'S repeated blows. BELLA  pulls JACK away.
Jack. Leave him! Come on!
JACK'S face is masked with blood and fury. BELLA is  frightened by JACK'S violence.
Let's go. We don't want the cops  here.
Before she can get JACK into her car, he goes back to the MAN groaning on the floor. He stamps on the MAN's hand.  BELLA is shocked.
(coldly) He won't cheat again.
BELLA pulls him away, bundles JACK into her car, gets in, drives away.
Water is running in the basin. BELLA puts JACK'S jacket o the lavatory seat. She starts to undo his tie. JACK wipes his blood-stained nose with a wet flannel.
You're shaking.
It's the tension.
She undoes his shirt and takes it off. He winces. She was his torso, cleans him up. JACK looks at his shaking hands. BELLA takes him by the  hand, leads him into the bedroom.
She sits him on the bed. The room is lit with coloured  lamps.
Excuse the mess.
JACK pulls her suddenly into his arms, pulls her onto the bed. She is startled.
Careful.
JACK'S hands open her blouse. He reaches for her breast.  BELLA'S surprise becomes excitement. He kisses her hungri his hands rummaging in her clothes. She reaches for a sid zip in her skirt.
Don't tear anything.

BELLA kicks off her shoes. There is a burst of passion  between them. For JACK, a continuation of the violence  with the MAN on the street. For BELLA, it's a sudden release. Her naked foot knocks  over the bedside lamp. JACK spreads BELLA on the bed. She tugs his trousers down He rips her black underwear away.
Later. JACK is lying sprawled on the bed with BELLA. She  reaches across him and retrieves the fallen lamp.
It's funny, isn't it? If that guy  hadn't come up to you, you wouldn't  be here now.
JACK strokes her bottom.
I hate cheats.
All men are cheats.
BELLA picks up a joint from the bedside and lights it.
I spent two years on the game. I  don't mind telling you that.
JACK looks at her.
But don't worry, I'm clean as a  whistle. I only did S & M. (she hands the joint  to JACK,) No blow jobs. No screwing.
Why did you quit?
I got scared.
(inhales) I can imagine.
Can you? I'm happy being a dealer.  At least the punters keep their  hands to themselves.
You called the casino a cesspit.
Well it is. But I know where I am.
JACK hands the joint back to BELLA.
I've been watching you work. You're  the best in the place. But you  know that.
I despise the job.
Ah, we all say that. But if we  hate it, why do we do it?
JACK doesn't answer.
Jack wanted to say we do it for  the money. But that wasn't really  true.
BELLA leans over JACK and begins gently to massage his  flesh.
What do you really want to do?
She puts the joint in an ashtray.
The Indian rope-trick.
Look, now I'm pumping you. I'm  sorry. It's none of my business.   It's just that you're not like the  others.
Not like Matt, you mean.
Now he's a real shit. Don't get  friendly with him. I'm sure he's  got his hand in the till. You know  what he said to me once? "I want  to fuck the whole world over. That's  my mission." The shit!
BELLA touches a bruise on JACK'S body.
Ouch.
Sorry.
She kisses the bruised skin, pulls him to her. BELLA simp wants to be held.
Jack could hear Matt saying it...
JACK is at his desk typing intently. There is a pile of  new pages in the sunlight.
"I want to fuck the whole world  over. It's my mission."
MARION passes in the foreground. She kisses him on the  back of his head and leaves. JACK'S fingers move across  the keyboard, dancing.
At last he had found what he'd  been looking for. A clear and simple  theme. And a hero to act it out.  Little Matt... (Pause) ...Chapter One.
MATT is shaving.
I look like shit.
JACK is scrubbing his nails at a basin.
Rough day?
Rough life, Jack.
A YOUNG WOMAN appears in the mirror behind the two MEN.  Her name is PAT. She is dressed like BELLA.
Hi. I'm Pat.
MATT and JACK say 'Hello'. MATT appraises PAT'S appearanc winks approval at JACK.
(to Matt) What happened to Bella?
I'll tell you later.
JACK is mystified.
JACK is dealing to MR TCHAI and three OTHER MEN. One chai at the table is empty.
What happened to Bella?
She was re-assigned.
JACK shows 13. He turns over his third card, a King. The  bank busts. JACK pays out. JANI sits down in the vacant chair. JACK conceals his  surprise, a hint of nervousness.
(formally) Good evening.
JANI nods impassively.
Jack knew this was no coincidence.  Why had she come?
The MEN look at the glamorous woman. MR TCHAI doesn't  register her presence. He is as inscrutable as his BODYGU who hands him an envelope. JANI takes out money from her  purse. JACK counts it.
One thousand even. In fifties.

JACK slots the money down, counts out 20 50 chips. JACK  deals. Bets are placed. 100 from JANI. The cards turn. MR TCHAI splits two aces. JANI has a 6 and 7. MR TCHAI recei two los and wins big. JANI gets a 10 and busts.
He wondered if she believed he  would bring her luck...
JANI'S face is impassive. She receives her cards...
JANI busts again. JACK sweeps away the chips, the cards.  JANI reaches into her bag, takes out another thousand  pounds.
In fifties.
The MEN at the table look at JANI.
Or did she think he would help her  win?
JANI loses again. She is down to 4 chips. She looks up at JACK. Their eyes meet, hers desperate, his helpless. MR  TCHAI picks up on the look.
He knew how to fix it for her. His  father had taught him the trick.  Switch the sequence. Bust the bank.  The casino wouldn't spot it. But  Jack was wary of the punters...
JACK glances at the MEN at the table.
He could see Mr Tchai was counting.  He couldn't risk it.
JANI places her last bet, glances at the mountain of chip in front of MR TCHAI. JACK catches her look. He deals.  JANI reaches for her next card. JACK observes her left  hand.
He noticed she wasn't wearing her  ring. Why not? Odds on she'd sold  it.
JACK plays out the hand. JANI loses. She immediately gets up. She is crushed.
Good night. Thank you.
She walks away from the table.
Good night.
Thank you, she said. For what,  Jack thought. Jani de Villiers  knew the odds.
TCHAI looks at JACK.
Pretty woman.

JACK is sitting on the bed fully clothed. He is carefully sewing a button on his croupier's jacket. Through the ope bedroom door MARION can be seen sitting on the sofa, legs tucked under her, reading the new typescript. The phone rings. In the bedroom JACK picks up.
Hello...
JACK SR. is in a public phone. Coloured lanterns hang rou in the night. Distant laughter.
How's it going, Jacko?
INTERCUT between JACK and JACK SR.
Fine. I took the job.
Good for you. I was wondering what  happened.
I tried to call you, dad, but they  said your line was disconnected.
(jovially) Ah yes, I moved house. Needed a  bigger place. How's that book of  yours coming along?
In the sitting room MARION looks towards JACK in the  bedroom.
I'm getting there.
It's good to have the job to fall  back on, isn't it? (pause) There goes my other phone.
Goodbye dad.
He hangs up. MARION turns the last page of the typescript She's finished.
JACK comes in from the bedroom. MARION says nothing. She  puts the typescript down. JACK waits. MARION gets off the sofa.
I don't like it.
Why not?
I don't like it at all. You had a  wonderful character before, the  Gambler. He was so romantic.
He was a loser. This guy's a  croupier. He can't lose. People  have shat on him all his life. Now  he's in control. He's a winner.
Is that your idea of a winner? He  doesn't give a shit about anyone.  He uses people and --
(interrupting) -- It's because of the sex, isn't  it? You don't like the sex in it.
I don't give a fuck about the sex.  Most men'll fuck a lamppost. He's  just a miserable zombie. Is that  the way you feel now? Is that what's  happened to you?
Marion. It's a book.
Oh really. Then why is he called  Jake. Why don't you come clean and  call him Jack. (softens) There's no hope in it.
It's the truth.
Without hope there's no point to  anything.

Now wait a minute. What's so hopeful  about your job? Spending the day  catching poor people stealing. You  said yourself the organised gangs  get away with it. At least in the  casino everybody gets caught. Rich  or poor, the odds are the same.  It's all relative.
Crap. It's not relative. It's  unfair. Like your casino. It's  designed unfair. And your croupier's  a little shit because he goes along  with it.
JACK sees MARION is getting really angry. He crosses the  room, Pointedly takes MARION'S handbag, opens it, takes  out a National Lottery card and receipt. The doorbell rin
(coldly) You're just like all those other  dummies out there. Fourteen and a  half million to one! Is that your  idea of hope?
The doorbell rings again.
The door, Jack.
Leave it.
No. Answer it!
JACK hands her the lottery card and goes to the door, ope it.  BELLA stands there.
You fucking little shit! You shopped  me.
What are you talking about?
MARION watches, numb.
Reynolds got a doctor in. They  forced me to take a dope test. It  was positive. As you knew.
I don't know anything about it.
BELLA looks over to MARION.

Your boyfriend fucked me, smoked  my dope, then shopped me. What do  you think of that? I can't get a  job now. (to Jack) You bastard. You're no different  from Matt. A pair of vicious little  shits, that's what you are.
(firmly) Look Bella, I don't know anything  about this. You should talk to  Matt.
You're all scumbags.
I agree.
Without looking at MARION, BELLA suddenly kisses JACK on  the lips. BELLA looks hard at JACK, then leaves. JACK  pursues her.
BELLA runs up the iron stairs to the gate at the top.
Bella!
Without looking back she flings the gate shut, goes off  down the street. JACK turns.
Go on. Go after her!
MARION slams the door to the flat. JACK is half-way up th stairs, alone.
The rush hour. 6 in the evening. JACK watches MEN and WOM coming out the store.
Jack had no idea where Marion was  staying, or with whom. He realised  he knew little about her life. But  then, he had never asked about it.

JACK now sees MARION. He is about to go up to her, moving through the flow of the crowd, then he stops. A MAN in his 30s, tall with a moustache, greets MARION.  He's been waiting for her. JACK watches the two of them,  unseen. The MAN and MARION exchange a few words. She smiles, take his arm. He leans forward to kiss her.
For the first time in a long while  Jack thought about his mother.  She'd left when she couldn't take  it any more.  His father had said  'Don't worry, Jacko, she'll come  back.' She didn't.
JACK turns and walks away.
But Marion wasn't his mother...
JACK stands behind REYNOLDS who is playing back a video o the earlier incident in which MATT cheated with the GREEK
He's paying out in stacks of 25.
I can see.
He freezes the frame, presses a button, zooms in on the  detail of MATT's hand covering the chips. On another video monitor MATT is dealing blackjack. REYNO looks at the screen.
Little shit.
Chapter Three. His existence was  forming an interesting pattern of  betrayals. Sometimes he was unsure  whether he was the betrayer or the  betrayed.
REYNOLDS looks up from the screen.
(grudgingly) Thanks for the information.
A pleasure. Pity about Bella.
She was a real asset. But what  could I do?
JACK lights a cigarette.
(shakes his head) Sorry. No smoking in the Nest,  Jack.

Working at his computer, JACK lights one cigarette from  another. He pauses from his typing. On the desk beside hi is the note with JANI's phone number. He picks up the pho starts to dial, then stops, replaces the receiver. He loo distracted, lost. On the table MARION'S flowers are dead  in the vase.

JACK comes downstairs from the upper floor. He is looking at a book he has selected: 'SCARNE ON CARDS'. Across from the cash desk near the entrance a book signin is in progress. A small crowd surrounds a Middle Eastern  author called HABIB dressed in a kaftan. GILES is with  him. A PHOTOGRAPHER is there. A few camera flashes. GILES sees JACK at the cash desk. He is uncertain for a  moment, then smiles.
(calling) Jack!
Hearing his name, JACK turns. GILES comes over.
I thought it was you. It's the  hair!
(touching the back  of his neck) I'm working on that soccer story.
(vaguely) Right. (suddenly) Look, I must get back to Habib.
Habib?
My author. He's a Terrorist. He's  written a kill-and-tell book. (puts his hand on  Jack's shoulder) Take care.
GILES heads back to the signing. The CASHIER puts JACK'S  book in a bag. GILES stops, thinking of something. He com back to JACK.

Jack, look, next weekend I'm having  a house party. Here... (removes a card  from his pocket  book) It's near Oxford. Why don't you  come? It'll just be social. No  business. (conspiratorially) Bring a friend. I've plenty of  room.
(looks at the card) I'll try and make it.
Looking forward!
GILES goes back to his group. JACK looks round the  bookstore, sees thousands of books in piles.
Books piled like chips. Stack 'em  high. Sell 'em fast. Make a killing.  You think you're a gambler, Giles,  but you're not. You're a dealer.
A camera flash.
JANI'S white Honda winds its way through the wintry  Oxfordshire countryside. The moon is bright.
Chapter Four...
JANI, wearing dark glasses, is driving. JACK, beside her, reads a map with a torch.
I don't know how you can drive at  night with those glasses.
She turns and smiles at him. Her left hand is bandaged.
How did you hurt your hand?
Just an accident. Nothing.
Turn left ahead.
The car turns into a lane.
Jani, there's something I want to  say. Before we get there. I don't  know what the sleeping arrangements  are. Giles probably expects us to  share a room.
That's fine.
The Honda's tyres crackle on the gravel drive which leads to a floodlit yellow stone country house. There are three cars parked outside the entrance. The Honda stops next to them.
JACK prepares to get out. JANI catches his arm. She takes off her dark glasses. Her right eye is bruised.
There's no point pretending it was  an accident. I had a fight with  someone, that's all.

A floodlit tennis court. A racquet smacks a tennis ball.  JACK sits with GILES drinking Bloody Marys watching a gam of mixed doubles. Everybody's wearing sweaters. JANI is playing with one of GILES'S friends, GORDON. On the other side, two girls,  FIONA from Giles' office, and CHLOE, Gordon's girlfriend. JACK follows JANI'S game. She is far and away the best of the four. GILES is also studying JANI's movements, her knickers whe she serves.
She's a dab hand With a racquet,  your friend.
South African women are very sporty.
JACK watches JANI'S strong leg muscles as she moves about the court.
I can see. How did she get that  shiner?
JACK has been waiting for this.
I found her in bed with someone.
(surprised) Who was he?
She.
I say. You're a dark horse, Jack.

On court, Jani delivers a winning overhead smash. The fou PLAYERS shake hands across the net. They come off the cou GORDON puts his arm around JANI. His girlfriend CHLOE  notices. JACK is irritated. GILES catches the moment.
(to Jack) You don't play tennis?
I don't play anything.
How boring for you.
JANI moves deliberately away from GORDON, who clearly  fancies her, and sits down beside JACK. She pointedly kis him on the cheek. GILES glances at GORDON, who shrugs.  FIONA comes up to GILES.
Where's our drinks?
They're so bloody selfish.
(to Jack) I'm so glad you brought me.
Jack wouldn't have come without  her.
JACK and JANI, GILES, GORDON and their two GIRLFRIENDS ar sitting down with drinks at a card table. GORDON opens a  fresh deck of cards.
I don't gamble.
Don't be a spoilsport. It's only a  few quid.
It's nothing to do with money. I  don't gamble.
GILES looks to JANI to persuade him.
He doesn't gamble.
I'll watch.
(insinuatingly) Jack likes to watch. (to Jani) Does he like to watch?
JACK is getting angry. JANI is calm.
(to Gordon) One more remark like that and I'll  break your balls.
There is silence. GORDON is embarrassed. FIONA looks at  CHLOE, they're shocked and impressed. JACK smiles.
(laughs) I'll bet she could, too.
JACK defuses the atmosphere.
I'll deal, but I won't play.
He sits down, picks up the cards.
You sure you know how?

JACK takes the pack of cards, splits it expertly into two shuffles by pressing the two halves together open-palmed. There is a rattling noise as the cards fold mechanically  into one another, leaving the pack as if it hadn't been  shuffled. FIONA and CHLOE are fascinated.
Do that again.

JACK gives the cards to his right, GORDON cuts them. Anot immaculate professional shuffle, and out come the cards  from JACK'S right hand, flicking across the table. As the cards land, they fall exactly next to one another  in front of each player.
That's sexy.
