Don't they look pretty.
They all pick up their cards.
(frowns) There's nothing pretty about this  hand.
You're not supposed to talk, Giles.
He's probably lying. He does that.
JACK catches JANI's eye. She winks.
Later. JACK deals the cards.
Last hand.
Hey. I've got an idea. Why don't  we...
(sharply) No! No stripping.
Right. We're not having that again! (glances at Jack) Although...
I'll stick to bluffing. That's  what I'm best at.

JANI smiles, says nothing. JACK slides the pack to JANI.  She looks up at him and cuts the cards. JACK deals the  cards deftly. The FIVE PLAYERS pick up their cards. Before each player calls we hear Jack's voice. In the end he correctly predicts their call. Is it telepathy? Or  something else?
I'll stick.
Two cards.
One card.
Oh I don't know...Er...two cards.
Three cards.
The PLAYERS examine their hands. The WOMEN are pleased.  The MEN say nothing. JANI puts her cards together. The betting begins. No one drops out. The raising goes  round three times.
That's it. I haven't got any more  cash.
The betting comes to an end. JACK watches as they turn  their hands over. GORDON turns over a Straight.
Beat that.
CHLOE turns over a Flush.
Ha. Ha. Ha.
Shit.
FIONA turns over a Full House.
Not so fast, darling.
(disbelieving) Hang on, chaps. That's impossible!
GILES turns over four of a kind.
How's about that for impossible.
Laughter, cries of amazement.
What's going on?
JACK is impassive. They all look to JANI, who turns over, one card at a time, a Straight Flush.
Wow. What are the odds for this  happening?
More laughter, cries of amazement.
Thousands to one.
Approximately.
I could've won if I'd been able to  bluff.
JANI leans forward and takes the pot. GILES looks at JACK then at JANI.
I get it.
Get what? (smiles) Are you accusing me of cheating?
Good God, no. But with skill like  that, what do you want a job for?  You don't need to work.
JACK sits on the side of a four-poster bed and takes off  his shoes. On the other side of the bed JANI unzips her  skirt. She looks round the room.
Here was an interesting question.  Was writing work... or play?

JANI puts her skirt over a chair and goes into the bathro She doesn't close the door. JACK continues undressing.  From a hold-all he removes a pair of pajamas. He glances  at the open bathroom door, then climbs into his pajamas.  He has two ugly bruises on his chest from the fight with  the ARABIC MAN. JANI comes out of the bathroom naked. She sees his body.
What happened?
Remember the guy who cheated at  the table?
You don't like cheats, do you.

She walks across to her case, opens it, rummages around  and takes out a nightie. This, without the slightest hint of embarrassment. JACK goes into the bathroom to brush hi teeth. JANI climbs into bed.
Which side do you like?
(calling) You choose.
They get into bed.
That trick tonight, I don't think  I've ever seen that before.
It can only work with amateurs, A  pro would have spotted it.
I didn't.
Then you're not a pro.
JANI leans over and turns off the lamp. Her hair brushes  JACK'S face.
Goodnight.
In the deserted hall is a nineteenth century painting, a  copy of Gericault's 'Raft of the Medusa'. The picture lig illuminates the group of men and women, clinging to the  raft and to each other.
Jack...? I need your help...
JACK wakes drowsily.
I'm in trouble.
What kind of trouble?
I owe a lot of money.
Was that why you did the two grand?  I couldn't help you.
I know that. But you can now.
I don't have any money.  switches  on the light. JANI is looking  distressed.
Some people I know, they're planning  to rob The Golden Lion.
JACK sits up, turns on the lamp.
You don't mean that.
JANI pulls up the bedcover around her body.
They mean it.
Who's they?
My creditors. One night, around  three in the morning, they'll come  into the casino -
(interrupting) Forget it, Jani. It'll never work.
The point is, they want a man  inside.
(laughs) And I thought you were a bright  woman.
Just listen. You don't have to do  anything criminal.
(smiles) Robbery's not criminal?
JACK gets out of bed, tours the room.

You don't have to be criminal. A  man will come up to your table and  deliberately cheat. You'll see  him, stop him, and the guy will  make a big scene. There'll be chaos.  And that's when it'll happen.
You're serious.
You won't be committing a crime.  The man will cheat, you'll just be  doing your job, that's all.
JACK comes right up close to JANI in bed.
And I thought you were only after  my body.
I've come to know you. You're  honest. (takes his hand) I trust you.
What'll you do when it all goes  wrong?
It won't.
But if it does.
You keep the ten thousand pounds.
What ten thousand pounds?
JANI gets out of bed.

These people will pay you ten  thousand before and ten thousand  after. They want someone they can  be sure of, an honest dealer. That's  the point. Not all dealers are  honest. Mr Reynolds will never  suspect you.
Reynolds? You've done your research.
She puts her hand on his.
I didn't know what else to do.  You're my last chance.
She takes his hand and puts it on her bruised eye.
Next time it'll be my neck.
What about my neck?
JANI is close to breaking down. Her toughness evaporates.
I want to go back to Cape Town, I  want to start again, clean.
I can't do it, Jani.
I'm asking you, as a...friend.  You'd be saving the life of a  friend.
JANI goes back to bed. She turns out the light. JACK stan in the middle of the dark room.

JACK comes out of the bedroom in his pajamas, wearing his hat. He walks slowly down the passage. He hears the sound of love-making coming from one of the rooms. He passes  'The Raft of the Medusa' as he goes down the stairs.
JACK comes into the kitchen, switches on the light. He  goes to the refrigerator, takes out a bottle of vodka. He washes a dirty glass and pours himself a drink.
Jack wondered why he was even  considering it. Ten grand. In cash.  That was why. But Jack didn't need  the money. His father would have  taken it, like a shot. But his  father was a gambler.
He downs his drink, and leaves the kitchen.
JACK walks back to his room. There is silence now, no sou of sex.
He was always broke. Jake suddenly  realised... it was Jake who was  considering it.
JACK comes in, tosses his hat on the bed. JANI isn't in  the bed. The bathroom door is afar. He hears the sounds o gasping. He rushes to the bathroom.

JANI is holding her head over the lavatory bowl. JACK run some water in the basin. He helps her to her feet and giv her a glass of water. She washes out her mouth. She looks at him, tears running down her face.
I want you to forget what I said.
Wait a minute...
No, forget it. The bet's off.
She reaches forward for a toothbrush and starts to clean  her teeth.
What about your father? Can he  help?
She spits the water out of her mouth, kisses him on the  forehead and goes back into the bedroom. JACK looks at hi reflection in the bathroom mirror. He strokes his hair  down.
Why don't you just go back to South  Africa?
He leaves the bathroom.
JACK gets back in bed with JANI. They turn away from each other and prepare to sleep.
How much do you owe?
Let it go.
Did they tell you to sleep with  me?
I told you, all bets are off.
JACK wakes as JANI is dressed getting ready to leave. She bends and kisses him.
I'm sorry.
What for?
I have to take the car.
She looks at him then leaves the room
Hang on tightly... let go lightly.
JACK comes into the kitchen. GILES is making coffee. CHLO is sitting at the table, half-asleep in her nightgown.
Good night?
Not particularly.
And your lady?
She had to leave early. She asked  me to thank you.
A bit unexpected, wasn't it?
Not entirely.
How's that football story corning  along?
You said it was going to be social,  Giles. No business.
He was overcome with a sense of  urgency. He had to get it down...  Chapter Five.

JACK comes in, puts down his overnight bag. He yawns, hea for the bedroom. Suddenly, he sees that the vase of dead  flowers is now full of fresh blooms. Underneath is a smal box, gift-wrapped. JACK opens it. Inside the tissue paper is a tiny gold charm on a chain. He examines it. CLOSE-UP: The charm is a book, no title engraved. JACK is touched.

JACK comes into the room. MARION is in bed asleep. He loo at her, smiles. He starts to get undressed. MARION stirs. JACK puts the  book charm around his neck. She moves from the middle to  one side of the bed, making room for him. He holds the  charm.
It's beautiful. Thank you.
I hope it brings you luck.
It will.
MARION I haven't brought you much luck, have I? Perhaps w shouldn't be together.
That girl, she works at the casino --
-- I don't care about her. Of  course, I was angry. But not with  you. The book is yours not mine. I  was wrong, what I said about it. I  hurt you, didn't I?
You're entitled to your opinion.
It's none of my business what you  write. And your job, that's none  of my business either. I love you.  And I've done everything wrong.
JACK takes her in his arms.
I'll leave the casino soon. (he strokes her  hair) I promise.
You will?
Within a month. Believe me, I'm  going to quit!
They begin to make love. She holds the back of his head.
Then you can dye your hair blond  again.
JACK is asleep in bed with MARION. He is murmuring  indistinguishable words. It wakes her. She gently touches his shoulder. He opens his eyes.
What?
You were talking in your sleep.
Not talking. Writing.
JACK is at work alone. The phone rings. He leaves it and  continues I working. Then he hears JANI'S VOICE.
I need to see you. I've moved. I  have a new number. It's 468-3275.  Please call me.
There is a click. JACK scribbles the number down and resu work.

JACK gets off a train. He is dressed as a croupier. He  walks to a public telephone on the platform, taking JANI' note from his pocket. He dials the number. The noise of  the train and PASSENGERS makes it difficult to hear. The  phone at the end rings and rings. JACK waits.
I want to speak to Jani de  Villiers... (waits) Jani... it's Jack... I'll come  over now...
He takes out a notepad and writes down the address.
JACK walks down a street of rough, transient's hotels. Th street lamps are on.
Chapter Seven... Jack had decided  to see her. The challenge was  essential.
He comes up to a hotel called 'Journey's End'. He goes in
JACK climbs the creaking stairs under the fluorescent  lights. He knocks on a door. JANI opens it. She wears men pajamas. She looks unslept.
Come in.
She glances up and down the passage. JACK goes in.
JANI carefully closes the door. JACK looks round the ding room.
It's not the Ritz this time.
She switches on a standard lamp, looks at him.
Is it yes?
Yes.
Thank you.
Reflected in a mirror, she opens her bag and takes out an envelope, gives it to JACK. He looks inside. Four bank  packets of 2500.
It doesn't seem fair. You're  offering me ten grand in cash but  you can't afford a decent place.
Well, life's not fair. We know  that.
It's all relative.  I need the  money too.
Do you?
Yes.
The date's not set yet. I'll call  you. One last thing: the man you're  going to catch cheating, he may  get violent. But you know how to  deal with cheats.
(looks at her face) That bruise has cleared up nicely.
Bruise? (touches her eye) Oh, yes. It's better.
(touches his chest) I've still got mine.
JACK looks at her hand.
And your hand too.
(coolly) I took the bandage off yesterday.
She crosses to pick up a bottle of Scotch.
Would you like a drink?
No thank you.
JACK puts the envelope in his pocket. They look at each  other.
I don't think we should meet again.
(nods) It's a shame there aren't more men  in the world like you.
JACK goes up to JANI and kisses her on the mouth. She put an arm around him.
There was a part of Jani he really  liked.
He turns and leaves the room.
JACK comes out of the hotel, walks up the street.
Question: Was he gambling, taking  Jani's money? Answer: No. Because  he wasn't betting with his own  money. He was being paid in advance  for a service...
At the roulette table JACK spins the wheel, throws the  ball.

In reality there were two clear  elements of risk in this exchange.  One: the possibility the cash was  counterfeit. Two: the possibility  Jani or her creditors would want  the money back if the plan failed.
A MIDDLE-AGED MAN is sweating. He fingers his last 2 chip He reaches for a number, hesitates. JACK sees that the  MAN's hand is shaking.
To begin with he put the odds at 2  against. 7 for. He checked a random  selection of bills at a bank. They  were all good.

Across the table a well-dressed JEWISH WOMAN in her fifti is sitting next to a YOUNG MAN, a gigolo type, the top  three buttons of his shirt undone. She too hesitates with her bet, looks down at her card, marked with the last thi turns.

So now his odds were decidedly  better. He put them at 8 to 1. The  fact that the notes were good gave  him one less negative. 2 minus 1.  At the same time mathematically he  had one more positive. 7 plus 1.
The WOMAN looks up at the YOUNG MAN. She hands him the  chip.
Bring me some luck.
The YOUNG MAN smiles. Takes the chip and puts it on 21. The MIDDLE-AGED MAN puts his chips on 8 and 11. He prays  silently.
The roulette table. The ball is bouncing in and out of  numbers.
No more bets.
The MIDDLE-AGED MAN closes his eyes. The WOMAN puts her  hand on the YOUNG MAN'S arm.

Next stage. He had to be secure at  8 to 1 against having to give the  money back, so he wouldn't spend  it. If after one month no one had  approached him, he calculated the  odds of keeping it at 20 to 1.  After three months he figured 100  to 1 no one would turn up.

The ball bounces into 21. The WOMAN gives a cry of joy.  She grips the YOUNG MAN's hand. He leans over to her, eye her diamond necklace, and whispers something seductive in her ear. She stiffens with apprehensive pleasure. The MIDDLE-AGED MAN opens his eyes, there is a look of  misery on his face. JACK sweeps away the lost chips, pays out five minor  winners. He calmly counts a small pile of chips and slide them to the MIDDLE-AGED MAN by sleight of hand. Then he  prepares to pay out the WOMAN. No one has noticed the pay-out to the MIDDLE-AGED MAN. Th MAN looks at JACK incredulously. JACK smiles mechanically The MAN mouths the words 'Thank you' to JACK. The WOMAN looks up at the YOUNG MAN. She gives him a pile of chips. He gives them back. He kisses her neck.
How about a drink to celebrate?
The MIDDLE-AGED MAN stands up, his face creased in emotio relief.
(to Jack) Cash me in.

JACK converts the green coloured chips to 35 in house  chips. The MAN nods at JACK, who smiles formally. The MAN leaves the table. PUNTERS place their bets for th next spin. JACK sees the MAN stop by the next roulette  table.
Jake's experiment with the man  would prove the point.
The MAN hesitates. He can't resist. In CLOSE-UP: the MAN puts two of the chips down.
People don't change.
MARION drops a plate as she's drying the dishes. She swea and bends to pick up the pieces.

MARION, undressed, pulls the old nightgown from the laund basket. She lets it fall back, goes to look in the chest  of drawers for another. She can't find one among the  underwear. She goes on to JACK'S drawer and pulls out a shirt. She  unfolds it. Out drop the four packets of 2500. She bends to pick them up. She looks at them incredulousl
JACK pushes several 50 notes into the slot and counts out two piles of chips for a PUNTER in front of him.
He watched their faces as they  lost hour after hour, night after  night, relentlessly.
JACK'S FACE as he deals.
He questioned the conventional  wisdom that gamblers are self- destructive...
The FACES of PUNTERS around the table: concentration,  grimness, apprehension...
He had come to believe that in  reality, they want to destroy  everyone else - their families and  loved ones, everyone. Fuck over  the whole world...
The white balls lands. The FACES of the LOSERS, resigned, desperate, angry.... The PUNTERS who are cleaned out get off their chairs, tea up their sequence cards, turn and walk away, quickly,  slowly.
Without emotion he watched them  go. Jake stayed.
MARION is lying awake alone in bed. The phone rings. She  leans over to pick it up, then doesn't. From the sitting  room comes the message:
It's set. The day after tomorrow.  The twenty-fourth. Good luck.
Click. MARION gets out of bed. She goes into the sitting  room.
MARION replays the message. She stares at the phone. Then carefully she presses the ERASE button, wiping the messag She goes back into the bedroom.
JACK is at work. MARION'S hands are massaging his shoulde The little book charm dangles round his neck.
Aren't you ever tempted to gamble?
(looks up) Never. Why do you ask?
I can just imagine, being around  so much money all the time...
Gambling's not about money.
Really?
Gambling's about not facing reality.  Ignoring the odds.
She takes her hands away from his neck.
I must be a fool. I never think  about the odds.
The sound of an underground train.
JACK sits impassively among noisy Christmas TRAVELLERS.  The train stops. SOMEONE pops a balloon. JACK gets up and alights, followed by a streamer. He disappears into the  crowd.
JACK hangs up his hat and coat, examines himself in the  mirror. He picks up a small roll of paper. He unfurls it. A Christmas party hat.
Chapter Twelve...

A Christmas festive atmosphere. The casino interior is  decorated with red and green balloons, silver and gold  streamers, a large tree hung with 1000 chips. JACK is dealing at a blackjack table. Like the other  croupiers and dealers, he is dressed in a fancy red coat  with green trim. He wears a silly paper hat. The PUNTERS at Jack's table include MR TCHAI and four  expensively dressed CHINESE MEN. The BODYGUARD stands beh them. They are gambling big money. Wads of 50 notes are  changed into 100 chips. JACK is coolly winning for the house. REYNOLDS looks on  impassively in his Santa Claus suit. Three or four PUNTER are watching the CHINESE lose heavily. MR TCHAI and his  friends occasionally exchange a phrase in Chinese but the show no emotion as they lose. With each hand they prepare to lose even more. JACK pushes hundreds of pounds into th box beneath the table. REYNOLDS signals a SECURITY MAN to collect the cash which is building up. He comes over with a safety cart. During short break the money is taken from under the table in a  box, loaded into the cart and wheeled away.

TWO COLD-LOOKING MEN in suits are drinking mineral water  at the bar. They watch the SECURITY MAN with the cart pas by and disappear through a green baize door marked PRIVAT One of the SUITS looks at his watch: five minutes to  midnight.

JACK is now at a roulette table. He sees a PUNTER's watch 2.45. The atmosphere around the crowded table is noisy,  laughter, loud voices. 1 One of the two MEN in suits from the bar eases himself into a chair. JACK sees him. The  SUIT throws him 500.
Fifties. Ten of them.
What colour chips?
Whatever.
JACK gives him ten pale blue chips and puts another pale  blue chip into the rack alongside the rainbow of colours  used by the other punters. The SUIT looks at his watch.

Two men in raincoats, DETECTIVES, approach REYNOLDS and  talk to him. REYNOLDS becomes nervous, looks around the  casino. The table at the bar where the SUITS sat is empty The PRIVATE green baize door slowly closes.

The ball bounces into number 5. There are cheers of delig from the winners, 5 is heavily covered. The SUIT casually slides a pale blue chip onto the number at the side. JACK Sees the obvious cheat. So do other PUNTERS.
(stiffens) Sir, I can't accept that bet.
The SUIT gets up and comes around the table to JACK.
Are you calling me a cheat?
You are a cheat. I saw you.
(grabbing Jack's  lapel) I'm talking to you.

JACK pushes him away. The SUIT hits JACK'S face with his  fist. Uproar around the table. JACK hits the man. The SUI grabs JACK and pushes him backwards across the table,  knocking all the chips over. The PUNTERS start shouting.  They grab their chips, especially the losers. One PUNTER  tries to restrain the SUIT. JACK kicks the SUIT hard. The fight, trading blows. At the blackjack table MR TCHAI and the other CHINESE see the fight. MR TCHAI barks at the BODYGUARD in Chinese. Th BODYGUARD heads for the fight at the roulette table. TWO DEALERS rush over to stop the fight. Somewhere in the distance there is the sound of a gunshot. PEOPLE start  screaming. The SUIT punches JACK in the stomach. JACK  doubles up. The SUIT breaks away, rushes across the casin pushing screaming WOMEN aside, heads for the door. MR  TCHAI's BODYGUARD blocks his way and fells the SUIT with hammer blow to the head. The TWO DETECTIVES come up. One of them handcuffs the SUI who is lying on the floor. The casino is in uproar. A  strange, violent Christmas party.
JACK lies groaning on the floor. MR TCHAI is standing,  watching JACK. REYNOLDS'S VOICE comes over the tannoy  system:
Ladies and gentlemen, please be  calm. There's no cause for alarm.  Enjoy yourselves. It's Christmas.

REYNOLDS'S VOICE is replaced by a breezy version of 'Rudo the Red-Nosed Reindeer'. JACK struggles to his feet, amid the chaos. He falls back in pain. MR TCHAI and the other  CHINESE leave the casino with the BODYGUARD.
JACK is sitting in a Christmas-decorated cubicle, a curta drawn round. An INDIAN NURSE is bandaging his arm. He has two large plasters on his chest. The NURSE finishes the job, smiles.
There you go.

She hands him two pills and a glass of water. In the  background there are party sounds. The NURSE leaves. JACK fingers the charm around his neck. There is a pause. Then the curtain is pulled back. MARION enters. She carries a bottle of wine and two cartons of  Chinese take-away. JACK is surprised.
How did you know I was here?
I thought you wouldn't want to  spend Christmas Day alone in here.
She starts to pour wine. JACK is still puzzled.
Did you go to the casino?
MARION hands him a glass of wine.
Happy Christmas.
They touch glasses and drink.
Now...noodles or rice?
As she opens the cartons, JACK watches her, still uneasy.
(quietly) I don't want a criminal for a  boyfriend.
(suddenly) There was a message, wasn't there?
It's probably easier for you to  eat the rice.
Marion!  What did you tell the  police?
Nothing about you.
Then what?
Give up being a croupier, Jack. Or  I'll shop you. All you have to do  is keep your word. It's that simple.
JACK sinks back on the bed. She hands him the rice dish.
Here...use a spoon.
Leave me alone, Marion.
You're already alone.
He had always been alone. He had  always believed it would make the  decisions easier.
All right. I don't want to lose  you. I'll quit. I swear to you.
MARION kisses him.
Why did you take the money?
I hate public transport.
What?
I want to buy a car.
(laughs) How can anyone be that naive?
JACK sits in front of REYNOLDS.
How do you feel, Jack?
Bruised.
Take your time. Two weeks. Three  if you need it. We'll pay you sick  leave. I don't want to lose you.  You're a good man. Here...
He hands JACK an envelope.
What's this?
He opens the envelope. Inside is a casino cheque for 500.
(smiles) Happy New Year. Have a drink on  the company. You've earned it.
JACK is sitting at his computer, drinking vodka, dressed  in his CROUPIER'S suit.
Chapter Thirteen...
He types... On the SOUNDTRACK we hear the CASINO noise.

It's all numbers, the croupier  thought. A spin of the wheel. A  turn of a card. The time of your  life. The date of your birth. The  year of your death. In the Book of  Numbers the Lord said: 'thou shalt  count thy steps'.
There's a ring at the doorbell. He looks at his watch:  2.15a.m. The I ring comes again.
Jack thought, this is it. The famous  two in the morning knock at the  door.  It wad pay-back time.
JACK goes to the door. At the door. It was pay-back time. JACK goes to the door.
But he wasn't afraid. He hadn't  spent one penny of the ten grand.  He'd covered himself. He knew the  odds.
JACK calmly opens the door. A UNIFORMED POLICEMAN stands  there. JACK hadn't expected this.
Mr Manfred?
Yes...
The sound of the roulette ball bouncing against the numbe
A POLICE DOCTOR uncovers a body on a gurney. The sound of the ball find-ing a number. JACK can hardly bear to look. It is MARION. With emotion...
What were the odds of being killed  by a car... on New Year's Eve?
She was on her way home... to you.
No. She wasn't.

JACK looks away from MARION'S face. He sees the MAN with  the moustache, standing on the other side of the gurney,  the MAN he saw with MARION on the street. He is DETECTIVE INSPECTOR ROSS. JACK is disorientated.
Marion had been visiting his  mother...no, no, not his mother -  her mother.
(to Ross) She was visiting her mother. Her  mother. (suddenly) Who are you?
Detective Inspector Ross.
Who...
Ross.
Who did it? Tell me!
He grabs ROSS'S lapels. ROSS carefully removes JACK'S han
We think it's a hit-and-run. A  drunk driver, probably, But there  is a possibility of a revenge  killing.
(distraught) Revenge? For what? Whose revenge?
As you know, she was a WPC with  the Met. up until two years ago.
JACK fumbles in his pocket for a cigarette. There is a No Smoking sign on the wall. ROSS produces a Zippo and light JACK'S Gitane.
She called me last week. She'd got  wind of a planned robbery at your  casino.
What had that got to do with her  death?
You didn't recognise the man who  attacked you, did you?
(loudly) Of course I recognised him!
(surprised) You did?
I know a cheat when I see one. The  man was a cheat.
ROSS sighs, looks at MARION. JACK suddenly reaches down and pulls the white sheet back over MARION'S face.
(to Ross) Do you gamble?
ROSS is puzzled. JACK drops his cigarette on the floor,  grinds it with his shoe. ROSS gives JACK his card.
If anything occurs to you, call  me.
JACK walks away from ROSS without a word. The DOCTOR is  now filling out a form. From the door JACK looks back. ROSS waits for him to say  something. JACK doesn't speak.
I was in love with her, you know.
There is a REPRISE of JACK covering MARION'S face with th sheet.
In his croupier's suit JACK walks the night streets.

(quoting) 'The world breaks everyone, and  afterward many are strong at the  broken places. But those that will  not break, it kills. It kills the  very good and the very gentle and  the very brave impartially. If you  are none of these, you can be sure  it will kill you too but there  will be no special hurry'.
He passes a poster for the National Lottery bearing the  legend: 'IT COULD BE YOU'. JACK doesn't see it.

A WOMAN smashes a plate over a MAN'S head. It's plate- smashing party time, Greek-style. TWENTY drunk PEOPLE hav fun. Zorba music. Plates are thrown, stamped on, smashed. JACK sits alone at a corner table, drinking, watching the fun, unsmiling. One plate cracks into a wall behind him. MAN stumbles backwards into JACK's table. JACK swiftly  moves his drink out of the way. The MAN apologises, turns to JACK. It is MATT.
Jacko! How're you doing? (shakes Jack's hand  vigorously) I heard about the raid. Pity they  didn't pull it off. I wish I'd  been there.
MATT has to shout above the noise and music. JACK smiles.
(quietly) But you were there Matt.
MATT doesn't hear.
What? You know what happened to  me, don't you? That bitch Bella  shopped me. I'd like to beat the  shit out of her.
I'd like to buy you a drink.
Cheers. Happy New Year. I really  like you, Jacko, you're so fucking  straight. (suddenly) Hey, you haven't changed your  clothes!
There are four or five PEOPLE left among the debris. MATT has gone. JACK is still there, drunk now.
The music stopped, Jack was drunk...  hallucinating. He was back, as a  child, in the Wild Coast Casino.
A BLACK WOMAN comes over to him. Her name is LUCY.
You've been avoiding me.
(blearily) Have I?
I'm Lucy.
And what do you do, Lucy?
I'm a witch. A white witch. Why  don't we move on?
Are you going to put a spell on  me?
I might.
LUCY guides JACK to a parked car. He is drunker than she. When he sees the car he starts to laugh. It is his Austin Healey.
Nice car. How much did you pay for  it?
Too much. Eighteen hundred.
She opens the door for him. They climb in. LUCY starts th car.
Where to?
Turn left at the lights.
They drive off.
A deserted intersection. The Austin Healey swings around corner.  A WOMAN steps out from the kerb.
JACK reacts. He swings the wheel. LUCY shouts. The car  swerves, missing the WOMAN.
Hey! I saw her!
JACK looks back. The WOMAN is shouting after the car.
You don't trust women drivers, do  you?
Jack didn't trust anyone. Except  himself.
JACK sits at his computer. He is watching the printer  unloading page after page. JACK assembles the typescript.
It was finally finished. He thought  of sending it to Giles. But that  wouldn't be right. He would select  a publisher at random, like a  number.
CLOSE UP: The dedication: 'To Marion'. The sound of the ball bouncing against the wheel.
The ball falls into 10. JACK puts the doll on 10. No one at the table has the winning number. JACK sweeps  away the losing bets.
A Blackjack table. The bets are placed. JACK turns over  the bank's cards: a KING and an ACE. He takes all the chi from the five PUNTERS.
(to Jack) You're wasting yourself. With your  luck you ought to come over to our  side.
JACK comes up to a bookstore window. A sticker reads: 'IT A WINNER'. There are quotes blown up from the reviews: "A

head_text.subj: INCREDIBLE INSIDE JOB...IT'S ALL HERE, THE SYSTEMS, THE
SCAMS, THE SLEAZE...A TALE OF TRIUMPHANT DISGUST...OF

text: EXHILARATING CONTEMPT..." The display is just one book:  'I, CROUPIER'. Number 1 Bestseller.
Even his publisher had no idea who  the author was. He had done the  deal through a lawyer. It gave him  a good feeling, no one knowing...
REYNOLDS is reading the book. He laughs out loud at  something.
...It never occurred to anyone at  the Casino that the Golden Lion  had been his model. Why should it?  Weren't all casinos the same....
JACK is sitting in his croupier's suit on the crowded tub He sees a WOMAN reading 'I, CROUPIER'. For the first time we see the back cover...'by ANONYMOUS'.

...It gave him an exquisite  pleasure, being an underground  man. With all his money, he hadn't  even bought a car. Jack knew the  truth about himself, he was a one- book writer. A one time winner who  had quit while he was ahead...
Five in the morning.
He changed nothing in the flat,  bought nothing, spent nothing. The  only thing he did was to remove  the bars outside the window...
JACK comes in. The phone rings.
JANI is holding a mobile phone. In the background is the  casino room, the lights, colours, rattling sounds. She  waits.
JACK hesitates, then picks up.
Hello...
Jack! It's Jani.
The following conversation is INTERCUT.
Jani! Where are you?
Sun City. I've been meaning to  call you for months.
(smiles) How are you?
Great. I'm getting married. At  least, I think I am.
Did you solve your problems?
Yes. I'm all over that now. Jack,  hold on a minute. There's someone  here who wants to talk to you...
JACK waits.
A MAN'S hand takes the phone from JANI.
Jacko - how're you doing?
Dad!
JACK SR. his arm round JANI, talks into the phone.
I never thanked you properly for  your help. Jani told me you behaved  like a perfect gentleman throughout.  I knew you would. I know my son.
JACK'S face is a mask, tight, fixed.
The woman thinks I'm going to marry  her. But you know me. It's a shame  things didn't work out. But we saw  you all right. You didn't gamble  the ten grand, did you?
(huskily) As a matter of fact I did. But I  won.
That's my boy. How's that novel of  yours coming along?
JACK slowly puts the phone down. He takes a deep breath.  Then smiles.
So that was it. The final card.  Blackjack. His father, eight  thousand miles and twenty seven  years away, was still dealing to  his son Jack from the bottom of  the deck...
CLOSE-UP: A copy of the book: 'I CROUPIER'.
...But Jake the croupier had a  sense of humour.
Laughing, JACK pours himself a vodka, raises his glass.
To you. To both of you.
He drinks at a gulp. He turns. Standing in the doorway is BELLA, wearing a nightdress. She is sleepy.
What are you laughing at? Who was  that on the phone?
A couple I know are getting married.
BELLA puts her arms around him lovingly.
Fools.
A whistling sound...
We are back in the FIRST SCENE. The ball bounces around  the spinning wheel. The FACES of the PUNTERS. Frozen  expressions. They are almost still. We do not see the  croupier. Then...
Now he had reached the point where  he no longer heard the sound of  the ball...
Nothing moves except the little white ball in the spinnin wheel. The ball slows...
...the spin of the wheel had brought  him home to the place where he was  born.
JACK'S face. A hint of a smile.
The croupier's mission was  accomplished.
The ball falls into green Zero. JACK rakes all the chips  off the table. There are no winners. The film ends on a  CLOSE-UP of JACK'S face. A look of calm satisfaction.
At last he was Master of the Game.  He had aquired the power... to  make you lose.
